choices.text: It is a continuation of subclavian artery
It is crossed by pectoralis minor muscle
It extends from outer border of second rib to the lower border of teres minor
The second part of part of axillary artery is posterior to pectoralis minor muscle

questions.text: All are true regarding axillary artery except?
questions.solution:
Branches of axillary artery

  • Axillary artery extends from outer border of first rib to the lower border of teres major.
  • Pectoralis minor crosses the axillary artery and divides it into 3 parts.
    • First part – superior to the muscle.
    • Second part – posterior to the muscle.
    • Third part – inferior to the muscle.

questions.text: Which of the following muscle is supplied by the anterior division of mandibular nerve?
questions.solution:
Mandibular division of trigeminal nerve

  • Anterior division of mandibular nerve supplies lateral pterygoid, masseter and temporalis.
  • Medial pterygoid is supplied by the nerve to medial pterygoid which arises from the main trunk of the mandibular nerve.
  • Mylohyoid and the anterior belly of digastric are supplied by the inferior alveolar nerve. Inferior alveolar nerve is the larger terminal branch of the posterior division of the mandibular nerve.

choices.text: Superior root is the continuation of the descending part of hypoglossal nerve
Inferior root is derived from the 4th cervical spinal nerve
Lies embedded in the anterior wall of the carotid sheath

questions.text: Regarding ansa cervicalis, all are true except?
questions.solution:
Ansa cervicalis. Superior root – descending hypoglossal; Inferior root - descending cervical.

Inferior root of ansa cervicalis is derived from 2nd and 3rd cervical spinal nerves.

  • Ansa cervicalis is a thin nerve loop that lies embedded in the anterior wall of the carotid sheath.
  • It supplies sternohyoid, sternothyroid and inferior belly of omohyoid.
  • Fibers of the superior root are derived from the first cervical nerve.

questions.text: Roof the fourth ventricle is formed by all of the following except?
questions.solution:
Fourth ventricle - Sagittal section of the brain

Median eminence is seen in the floor of the fourth ventricle.

Roof of the fourth ventricle is formed by:

  • Superior medullary velum
  • Inferior medullary velum
  • Superior cerebellar peduncle
  • Tela choroidea of the the fourth ventricle
  • Taeniae with the obex

questions.text: The branch arising from the main trunk of mandibular nerve is?
questions.solution:
Mandibular division of trigeminal nerve

BRANCHES OF MANDIBULAR NERVE

  • From the main trunk:
    • Meningeal branch
    • Nerve to medial pterygoid
  • From the anterior trunk:
    • Buccal nerve
    • Masseteric nerve
    • Deep temporal nerve
    • Nerve to lateral pterygoid
  • From the posterior trunk:
    • Auriculotemporal nerve
    • Lingual nerve
    • Inferior alveolar nerve.

questions.text: Anterior wall of the third ventricle is formed by?
questions.solution:
Ventricles of the brain

  • Anterior wall of third ventricle is formed by lamina terminalis, anterior commissure and anterior column of fornix.
  • Posterior wall is formed by pineal body, posterior commissure and cerebral aqueduct.

choices.text: It is connected to the inferior colliculus
Layers 1, 4 and 6 receive the contralateral optic fibers
It is situated posterolateral to the medial geniculate body
It is overlapped by the lateral part of the temporal lobe

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the lateral geniculate body?
questions.solution:
• Lateral geniculate body is connected to the superior colliculus.
  • It is situated anterolateral to the medial geniculate body.
  • It is overlapped by the medial part of the temporal lobe.

choices.text: Leaves the femoral triangle by passing through the adductor canal
Femoral nerve is lateral to the upper part of the femoral artery in the femoral triangle
Femoral branch of genitofemoral nerve is lateral to the upper part of femoral artery within the femoral sheath
The medial cutaneous nerve of thigh crosses the artery from medial to lateral side near the apex of femoral triangle

questions.text: All are true regarding femoral artery except?
questions.solution:
Branches of femoral artery

  • The medial cutaneous nerve of thigh crosses the artery from lateral to medial side near the apex of femoral triangle.
  • Femoral artery passes downward and medially first in the femoral triangle and then in the adductor canal. At the lower end of the adductor canal, it passes through the opening in the adductor magnus to become continuous with the popliteal artery.

Contents of femoral sheath:

Lateral compartment – Femoral artery and femoral branch of genitofemoral nerve.

Middle compartment – Femoral vein.

Medial compartment – Lymph node of Cloquet.

questions.text: Deep perineal pouch in males does not include?
questions.solution:
Coronal section of pelvis. Deep perineal pouch is located between the superior and inferior layers of the urogenital diaphragm.

Long perineal nerve is located in the superficial perineal pouch.

Contents of deep perineal pouch in males:

Muscles - Sphincter urethrae, Deep transversus perinei.

Nerves - Dorsal nerve of penis, muscular branch from perineal nerve.

Vessels - Deep and dorsal arteries of penis, stem of origin of artery to the bulb of penis, urethral artery.

choices.text: Posterior surface of left suprarenal is related to kidney
Posterior surface of right suprarenal is related to inferior vena cava
Lateral border of left suprarenal is related to left gastric artery
Lateral border of right suprarenal is related to right coeliac ganglion

questions.text: Which is true regarding suprarenal gland?
questions.solution:
Relations of adrenal (suprarenal) gland

  • Posterior surface of left suprarenal is related to the kidney laterally and left crus of diaphragm medially.
  • Posterior surface of right suprarenal is related to right crus of diaphragm.
  • Anterior surface of the right suprarenal is related to inferior vena cavamedially.
  • Lateral border of left suprarenal is related to the stomach.
  • The medial border of the left suprarenal is related to the left gastric artery.
  • Lateral border of right suprarenal is related to the liver.
  • Medial border of right suprarenal is related to right coeliac ganglion.

questions.text: Pisiform is considered as a sesamoid bone in the tendon of?
questions.solution:
• Flexor carpi ulnaris is primarily inserted into the pisiform bone.
  • But the muscle action is transmitted through ligaments into the hamate bone (via pisohamate ligament) and the 5th metacarpal bone (via pisometacarpal ligament).
  • Hence, pisiform is considered as a sesamoid bone located in the tendon of flexor carpi ulnaris.

                            Pisiform bone

questions.text: Largest bursa in the human body is?
questions.solution:
• The largest bursa in the body is the subacromial bursa.
  • It is located beneath the coracoacromial arch and the deltoid muscle.
  • Supraspinatus tendon and the greater tubercle of the humerus is situated underneath the bursa.


Functions:

  • Prevents friction between supraspinatus tendon and acromion.
  • Facilitates the movement of the greater tubercle of humerus under the acromion process during overhead abduction.

questions.text: Which is not a part of the hypogastric sheath?
questions.solution:
Coronal section of the pelvis showing the layers of pelvic fascia.

  • Hypogastric sheath is a condensation of the pelvic fascia which transmits vessels and nerves along the lateral pelvic wall towards the pelvic viscera.
  • Broad ligament of uterus is not a part of the hypogastric sheath; it is a peritoneal fold.

Parts of the hypogastric sheath:

  1. Anterior lamina – Lateral ligament of bladder.
  2. Middle lamina – Transverse cervical ligament, rectovesical septum in males.
  3. Posterior lamina – Presacral fascia, uterosacral ligament.

questions.text: Chief pronator of the forearm is?
questions.solution:
Muscles involved in pronation of the forearm are:

  1. Pronator quadratus
  2. Pronator teres
  • The chief pronator is pronator quadratus.
  • It is assisted by the pronator teres to facilitate rapid movement and when the action is against resistance.
  • Gravity also assists in pronation.

questions.text: Supination of forearm with the elbow extended is brought about mainly by?
questions.solution:
Supinators of the forearm are:

  • Biceps brachii (Involved in rapid supination with elbow flexed and supination against resistance.)
  • Supinator (Mainly concerned with slow supination with elbow extended.)

questions.text: Oblique head of adductor pollicis arises from?
questions.solution:
• Oblique head of adductor pollicis originates from capitate and the bases of 2nd and 3rd metacarpals.
  • Transverse head originates from the palmar aspect of the third metacarpal.
  • It is inserted into the medial side of the base of the proximal phalanx of the thumb.

questions.text: Anterior choroidal artery is a branch of?
questions.solution:
Circle of Willis

  • Anterior choroidal artery arises from the internal carotid artery.
  • Anterior cerebral artery is a branch of internal carotid artery.
  • Posterior cerebral artery is a branch of vertebral artery.
  • Anterior communicating artery is a branch of anterior cerebral artery.

choices.text: Results from injury to neck of fibula

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding injury to common peroneal nerve is false?
questions.solution:
Nerves of the lower limb

FEATURES OF COMMON PERONEAL NERVE INJURY

  • Foot drop (due to paralysis of dorsiflexors of ankle)
  • Inability to dorsiflex toes (paralysis of extensor hallucis longus, extensor digitorum longus and extensor digitorum brevis)
  • Inability to evert the foot (the foot assumes an inverted attitude)
  • Anaesthesia of anterolateral aspect of leg.
  • Anaesthesia of dorsum of foot and toes with medial side of big toe.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a pneumatic bone?
questions.solution:
PNEUMATIC BONES



Paranasal sinuses: Frontal (1), Ethmoid (2), Sphenoid (3), Maxillary (4)

Pneumatic bones are those which enclose an air-filled cavity

They are seen in relation to the nasal cavity (paranasal sinuses) and the middle ear

The pneumatic bones are:

  • Frontal
  • Sphenoid
  • Ethmoid
  • Maxilla
  • Temporal (mastoid air cells)

questions.text: Muscles supplied by anterior division of mandibular nerve are all except?
questions.solution:
MUSCLES SUPPLIED BY MANDIBULAR NERVE

  • Mandibular nerve can be divided into 3 parts – main trunk, anterior division and posterior division.
  • Muscles supplied by main trunk:
    • Tensor veli palatini
    • Tensor tympani
    • Medial pterygoid
  • Muscles supplied by anterior division:
    • Lateral pterygoid
    • Temporalis
    • Masseter
  • Muscles supplied by posterior division:
    • Anterior belly of digastric
    • Mylohyoid

questions.text: Not included among posterior relations of head of pancreas?
questions.solution:
First part of duodenum lies anterior to the head of pancreas.

POSTERIOR RELATIONS OF HEAD OF PANCREAS:

  • Aorta ( lies posterior to uncinate process )
  • Inferior venacava
  • Terminal part of right renal vein
  • Bile duct
  • Right crus of diaphragm

questions.text: Where is the urethral crest located?
questions.solution: The posterior wall of the prostatic urethra contains a longitudinal midline ridge known as the urethral crest.

questions.text: Lymphatic drainage from the spongy urethra is towards?
questions.solution:
Lymphatic drainage of urethra

  • Prostatic and membranous urethra - Mainly to internal iliac lymph nodes, partly to external iliac lymph nodes
  • Spongy urethra - Mainly to deep inguinal lymph nodes, partly to superficial inguinal and external iliac lymph nodes

questions.text: Which is the type of joint seen in the growth plate?
questions.solution:
• Growth plate is a primary cartilaginous joint
  • They are also known as synchondrosis/hyaline cartilage joints
  • The bones are joined by a plate of hyaline cartilage
  • It does not permit any movement
  • Other examples: Costochondral joint, chondro-sternal joint, Spheno-occipital joint

questions.text: Which of the following gives rise to the muscular component of dorsal aorta?
questions.solution: Vascular smooth muscle cells are thought to arise from splanchnic layer of paraxial mesoderm. But recent studies have shown that the aortic smooth muscle cells arise from the lateral plate mesoderm.

questions.text: Toynbee's muscle is?

choices.text: Loose areolar tissue (Danger area of scalp)

questions.text: Deepest layer of scalp is:
questions.solution:
From superficial to deep, the layers of scalp are (mnemonic: SCALP)

  1. S – Skin
  2. C – Connective tissue (fibrofatty)
  3. A – Aponeurosis (Epicranial Aponeurosis)
  4. L – Loose areolar tissue (Danger area of scalp)
  5. P – Periosteum

questions.text: Which of the following movements will not be affected by involvement of the L5 Nerve root?
questions.solution: Thigh adduction is performed by adductor muscles (magnus, longus, brevis) with gracilis and pectineus acting as accessory muscles. None of them are supplied by L5 nerve root.

questions.text: The Couinaud's segmental nomenclature is based on the position of the :
questions.solution:
Couinaud’s segmental nomenclature is based on position of hepatic veins and portal vein. It is the French system.

  • Portal vein divides liver into various segments according to Couinaud's classification system.
  • 'Current understanding of the functional anatomy of the liver is based on Couinaud's division of the liver into (subsequently nine, then later revised back to eight) functional segments, based upon the distribution of portal venous branches and the location of the hepatic veins in the parenchyma


  • The liver is divided into four portal sectors by the four main branches of the portal vein. These are right lateral, right medial, left medial and left lateral (sometimes the term posterior is used in place of lateral and anterior in place of medial). The three main hepatic veins lie between these sectors as intersectoral veins. These intersectoral planes are also called portal fissures (scissures). Each sector is sub-divided into segments (usually two) based on their supply by tertiary divisions of the vascular biliary (Glissonian) sheaths.

questions.text: Which of following is the feature of Y chromosome?
questions.solution:
Y chromosome - Acrocentric

X chromosome - Submetacentric

questions.text: Which type of epithelium is found in thyroid follicles?
questions.solution: Thyroid follicles are reasonable for the production and secretion of thyroid hormone. They are made up of Cuboidal epithelium.

questions.text: When does the development of heart begin?
questions.solution: The heart and other organs start developing during 3rd week after conception. The baby’s brain and spinal cord will develop from neural tube.

questions.text: Human placenta is derived from _____________
questions.solution: Human placenta is derived from Chorion. The chorion and amnion together forms amniotic sac.

questions.text: Which of the following neuroglial cells forms part of the Blood Brain Barrier?
questions.solution:
• Astrocytes outnumber the neurons in the brain. They regulate blood flow in the CNS by acting as Blood Brain Barrier. The foot plates of astrocytes cover nearly 80% of capillary surface.
  • They take part in replacement gliosis following death of neurons.
  • They maintain and regulate synapses.
  • They also store and release nutrients especially in times of need like hypoglycemia.

questions.text: Which of the following structures is NOT pierced by the needle during epidural lumbar puncture?
questions.solution: • The anterior and posterior longitudinal ligaments are the long ligaments of the vertebral column holding the vertebral bodies together. The posterior ligament covers the posterior surface of the vertebral bodies. It lies anterior to the vertebral canal and therefore, need not be pierced either during this procedure or during withdrawal of CSF from the subarachnoid space.

questions.text: Efferent fibres from the cerebellum arise mainly from
questions.solution: • Efferents from the cerebellum arise mainly from the deep cerebellar nuclei. Afferents to the cerebellum end mainly in the cerebellar cortex. This is the basis of cerebellar circuitry.

questions.text: Which of the following is (are) NOT conveyed through the dorsal /posterior column tract?
questions.solution:
• The posterior column of spinal cord conveys sensation of discriminative touch and pressure, conscious sense of position and movements, sense of vibration and stereognosis. Recent studies have shown that proprioceptive fibres from muscle spindle (Ia fibres) and from Golgi tendon organs (Ib fibres) also pass in the posterior column.
  • Sensations of pain and temperature is conveyed through the lateral spinothalamic tract.
  • Sensation of crude touch and pressure is conveyed through the anterior spinothalamic tract.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of association fibres?
questions.solution:
• Corona radiata – Projection fibres
  • Tapetum, Forceps major and minor form parts corpus callosum in the midline –Commissural fibres.
  • Arcuate or Uncinate fasciculus – Association fibre bundle extending between the Motor speech area and the sensory speech area.

questions.text: Which of the following contains multipolar neurons?
questions.solution:
• Neurons of both sympathetic and parasympathetic ganglia are multipolar.
  • The neurons of the dorsal (spinal) root ganglia of spinal nerves and sensory ganglia of the cranial nerves (with the exception of first, second and eighth cranial nerves) are Psuedounipolar.
  • The neurons found in the semicircular canals and the Spiral ganglia of the VIII nerve, the Ganglion cell layer of retina and the neurons of olfactory nerves in the nasal mucosa are bipolar.
  • The fibres of the optic nerve extend from the bipolar neurons of the ganglion cell layer of retina.

choices.text: Conveying information to the motor area of the frontal lobe through corpus striatum
Providing mood (feeling tone) to the emotional aspect of behaviour
Receiving somatosensory impulses from the spinal cord and brain stem

questions.text: The medial group of thalamic nuclei is associated with
questions.solution:
• The medial group of nuclei is associated with providing mood (feeling tone) to the emotional aspect of behaviour.
  • The anterior group forms a part of Papez circuit and is associated with recent memory trace
  • The ventral-anterior (VA) nucleus conveys information to the motor area of the frontal lobe through corpus striatum.
  • The VPM nucleus is receives somatosensory information from the face and most of the head.
  • The VPL nucleus receives somatosensory information from the rest of the body.

choices.text: Carries parasympathetic fibres from the Edinger Westphal Nucleus through the nerve to inferior rectus
Supplies the inferior oblique muscle of the eyeball
Enters the orbit through the superior orbital fissure

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a true statement about the oculomotor nerve?
questions.solution:
• The Oculomotor (III cranial) nerve arises from the midbrain. Its nucleus lies at the level of the superior colliculus.
  • The parasympathetic fibres from the Edinger Westphal nucleus pass through the oculomotor nerve (nerve to inferior oblique) and are associated with the innervation of sphincter pupillae and ciliary muscle.
  • It is the main nerve of the extra-ocular muscles. It supplies all except the superior oblique and the lateral rectus. These muscles are innervated by the trochlear and the Abducens nerves respectively.

choices.text: Between the superior and middle constrictors
Between the middle and inferior constrictors
Between the thyropharyngeal and cricopharygeal parts of inferior constrictor

questions.text: The pharyngeal diverticulum occurs
questions.solution: • The pharyngeal diverticulum (Zenker’s diverticulum) is a pouch that occurs through a weak point (Killian’s dehiscence) in the posterior wall of pharynx between the two parts of the inferior constrictor muscle.

questions.text: What type of glands are Ceruminous glands?
questions.solution:
• Structurally, ceruminous glands are modified (apocrine) sweat glands secreting a waxy material known as cerumen.
  • The glands of Moll in the eyelids are also modified sweat glands.
  • Sebaceous glands discharge their secretion by holocrine mode.

Based on the modes of discharge, the exocrine glands are divided into three types.

  1. Eccrine (epicrine or merocrine) glands – they discharge their secretion by the process of exocytosis. E.g. Typical Sweat glands.
  2. Apocrine glands – In these glands, the apical part of cell membrane ruptures and the secretion is extruded into the lumen of the duct. Eg. Atypical sweat glands (glands in the axilla, areola and nipple, perianal skin, glans penis and glands in some parts of female genitalia).
  3. The secretions of apocrine sweat glands are viscous and contain proteins. They are odourless, but after bacterial decomposition, they give off body odours that differ from person to person.
  4. The mammary gland exhibits two modes of discharge. It discharges milk protein by eccrine mode and fat globules by apocrine mode.
  5. Holocrine glands – In these glands, the entire cell loaded with the secretion is extruded into the lumen of the duct. E.g. Sebaceous gland.

questions.text: Dermatomal supply of the marked area is by:
questions.solution:
• Umbilicus (the marked area in figure) has T10 Dermatomal supply.
  • The skin of anterior abdominal wall is innervated by ventral rami of T7to T12 spinal nerves (lower 5 intercostal and subcostal nerve) and ventral rami of L1 (iliohypogastric nerve).
  • Lateral cutaneous branches of T7 to T11 supply lateral part of skin of anterior abdominal wall.
  • Anterior cutaneous branches of lower 5 intercostals (T7 to T11), subcostal (T12) and iliohypogastric (L1) supply paramedian region emerging through anterior wall of rectus sheath.
  • The dermatomal pattern is arranged in serial order; T10 near xiphoid process (epigastric pit), T10 at umbilicus level, the iliohypogastric (L1) 2-5 cm above the superficial ring and others at proportionate distance between them.

DERMATOMAL DISTRIBUTION



(Ref: Snell's 9th /ep. 274, 388; Gray's 39th /e p. 1107)

choices.text: At the time of entry of spermatozoon

questions.text: When is the first polar body extruded?
questions.solution:
• The ovum completes its first meiotic division by extruding the first polar body just before ovulation (less than 24 hours).
  • It completes its second meiotic division by extruding the second polar body at the time of fertilization by a spermatozoon.
  • Note that, if fertilization does not occur, the ovum degenerates within 24 hours without even completing meiosis.

choices.text: Right and left Medial nasal processes

questions.text: A midline cleft lip is due to failure of fusion between
questions.solution:
• Failure of fusion between the right and left medial nasal processes (parts of frontonasal process) results in midline cleft lip (Hare lip).
  • Failure of fusion between the medial nasal and maxillary processes on one side or both sides results in unilateral or bilateral cleft lip.

choices.text: Second pharyngeal arch mesoderm gives origin to muscles of mastication
Branchial cyst is due to persistence of cervical sinus
Third pharyngeal arch artery (Aortic arch) gives rise to the Arch of aorta
Left subclavian artery is a derivative of fourth aortic arch

questions.text: TRUE about pharyngeal arch derivatives:
questions.solution:
• First pharyngeal arch mesoderm gives rise to the muscles of mastication; second arch mesoderm gives rise to the muscles of facial expression
  • Branchial cyst, sinus and fistula are due to persistence of cervical sinus. The cervical sinus is a gap between the descending flap of the second branchial arch mesoderm and the rest of the arches. This flap covers the arches laterally and fuses with the side of the neck caudal to the arches. This is how our neck becomes smooth.
  • Third pharyngeal arch artery (Aortic arch) gives rise to the Common carotid artery. The arch of aorta is derived from left 4 th arch artery.
  • It is the right subclavian artery that is derived from the right 4 th aortic arch. The left subclavian artery is not derived from the aortic arches. It develops from 7 th cervical intersegmental artery.

questions.text: A 21 year old man receives a penetrating knife wound in the abdomen. The superior mesenteric artery and the vagus nerve are injured. Which portion of the colon would most likely be impaired by this injury?
questions.solution:
Blood supply of gut:

  • Foregut: Coeliac trunk
  • Midgut: Superior Mesenteric Artery
  • Hindgut: Inferior Mesenteric Artery

Midgut structures:

The midgut consists of:

  1. Distal half of the duodenum
  2. Jejunum
  3. Ileum
  4. Cecum
  5. Ascending colon and
  6. Proximal half of the transverse colon

choices.text: pressing or tapping on the median nerve in the patient's wrist
asking the patient to flex the wrists while extending the fingers
asking the patient to flick the hand and wrist as if shaking a thermometer
elevating the patient's hand above his or her head as high as comfortably possible for one minute

questions.text: Phalen's manoeuvre consists of
questions.solution:
During Phalen's maneuver (wrist-flexion test), tingling or numbness may be produced by asking the patient to flex the wrists while extending the fingers. It tests for median nerve compression due to carpal tunnel syndrome. If symptoms occur within one minute, the presence of carpal tunnel syndrome is suggested.



Option A describes Tinel's test for carpal tunnel syndrome

questions.text: Which of the marked structures represents Medial Longitudinal fasciculus(MLF)?
questions.solution:
A - Oculomotor nucleus

B - Trochlear nucleus

C - Abducens nucleus

D - Vestibular nucleus

E - Medial Longitudinal Fasciculus

F - Pons

G - Fourth ventricle
